defs.docs:
The purpose of this library is to provide an OpenGL context on as many
 platforms as possible.

attributes.value: ! The purpose of this library is to provide an OpenGL context on as many
! platforms as possible.
! # Building a WindowedContext
! A `WindowedContext` is composed of a `Window` and an OpenGL `Context`.
! Due to some operating-system-specific quirks, glutin prefers control over
! the order of creation of the `Context` and `Window`. Here is an example of
! building a WindowedContext the prefered way:
! ```no_run
! # fn main() {
! let el = glutin::EventsLoop::new();
! let wb = glutin::WindowBuilder::new()
!     .with_title("Hello world!")
!     .with_dimensions(glutin::dpi::LogicalSize::new(1024.0, 768.0));
! let windowed_context = glutin::ContextBuilder::new()
!     .build_windowed(wb, &el)
!     .unwrap();
! You can, of course, create an OpenGL `Context` separately from an existing
! window, however that may result in an suboptimal configuration of the window
! on some platforms. In that case use "SeparatedContext".

defs.name: os
defs.docs: Contains traits with platform-specific methods in them.

attributes.value: ! Contains traits with platform-specific methods in them.
! Contains the following modules:
!  - `android`
!  - `ios`
!  - `macos`
!  - `unix`
!  - `windows`
cfg(target_os = "macos")

Returns a pointer to the `EGLDisplay` object of EGL that is used by this

attributes.value: / Returns a pointer to the `EGLDisplay` object of EGL that is used by this
/ context.
/ Return `None` if the context doesn't use EGL.

defs.name: Context
defs.docs: Represents an OpenGL context.

attributes.value: / Represents an OpenGL context.
/ A `Context` is normally associated with a single Window, however `Context`s
/ can be *shared* between multiple windows or be headless.
/ # Example
/ ```no_run
/ # use glutin::ContextTrait;
/ # fn main() {
/ # let el = glutin::EventsLoop::new();
/ # let wb = glutin::WindowBuilder::new();
/ # let some_context = glutin::ContextBuilder::new()
/ #    .build_windowed(wb, &el)
/ #    .unwrap();
/ let cb = glutin::ContextBuilder::new()
/     .with_vsync(true)
/     .with_multisampling(8)
/     .with_shared_lists(some_context.context());

defs.name: new_headless
defs.value:
pub fn new_headless(&winit::EventsLoop, ContextBuilder, dpi::PhysicalSize)
-> Result<Self, CreationError>
defs.docs: Builds the given GL context.

attributes.value: / Builds the given GL context.
/ One notable limitation of the Wayland backend when it comes to shared
/ contexts is that both contexts must use the same events loop.
/ Errors can occur in two scenarios:
/  - If the window could not be created (via permission denied,
/  incompatible system, out of memory, etc.). This should be very rare.
/  - If the OpenGL context could not be created. This generally happens
/  because the underlying platform doesn't support a requested feature.

defs.name: RawContext
defs.docs: Represents a raw OpenGL context.

attributes.value: / Represents a raw OpenGL context.

defs.name: swap_buffers
defs.docs: Swaps the buffers in case of double or triple buffering.

attributes.value: / Swaps the buffers in case of double or triple buffering.
/ You should call this function every time you have finished rendering, or
/ the image may not be displayed on the screen.
/ **Warning**: if you enabled vsync, this function will block until the
/ next time the screen is refreshed. However drivers can choose to
/ override your vsync settings, which means that you can't know in
/ advance whether `swap_buffers` will block or not.

defs.name: get_pixel_format
defs.docs: Returns the pixel format of the main framebuffer of the context.

attributes.value: / Returns the pixel format of the main framebuffer of the context.

defs.name: resize
defs.docs: Resize the context.

attributes.value: / Resize the context.
/ Some platforms (macOS, Wayland) require being manually updated when
/ their window or surface is resized.
/ The easiest way of doing this is to take every `Resized` window event
/ that is received with a `LogicalSize` and convert it to a
/ `PhysicalSize` and pass it into this function.

defs.name: WindowedContext
defs.docs: Represents an OpenGL context and the `Window` with which it is associated.

attributes.value: / Represents an OpenGL context and the `Window` with which it is associated.
/ # Example
/ ```no_run
/ # use glutin::ContextTrait;
/ # fn main() {
/ let mut el = glutin::EventsLoop::new();
/ let wb = glutin::WindowBuilder::new();
/ let windowed_context = glutin::ContextBuilder::new()
/     .build_windowed(wb, &el)
/     .unwrap();
/ unsafe { windowed_context.make_current().unwrap() };
/ loop {
/     el.poll_events(|event| {
/         match event {
/             // process events here
/     // draw everything here
/     windowed_context.swap_buffers();
/     std::thread::sleep(std::time::Duration::from_millis(17));

defs.name: new_windowed
defs.value:
pub fn new_windowed(WindowBuilder, ContextBuilder, &EventsLoop)
-> Result<Self, CreationError>
defs.docs:
Builds the given window along with the associated GL context, returning
 the pair as a `WindowedContext`.

attributes.value: / Builds the given window along with the associated GL context, returning
/ the pair as a `WindowedContext`.
/ One notable limitation of the Wayland backend when it comes to shared
/ contexts is that both contexts must use the same events loop.
/ Errors can occur in two scenarios:
/  - If the window could not be created (via permission denied,
/  incompatible system, out of memory, etc.). This should be very rare.
/  - If the OpenGL context could not be created. This generally happens
/  because the underlying platform doesn't support a requested feature.

Sets the multisampling level to request. A value of `0` indicates that
 multisampling must not be enabled.

/ # Panic
/ Will panic if `samples` is not a power of two.

defs.name: with_double_buffer
defs.docs: Sets whether double buffering should be enabled.

attributes.value: / Sets whether double buffering should be enabled.
/ The default value is `None`.
/ ## Platform-specific
/ This option will be taken into account on the following platforms:
/   * MacOS
/   * Linux using GLX with X
/   * Windows using WGL
inline

defs.name: with_hardware_acceleration
defs.docs: Sets whether hardware acceleration is required.

attributes.value: / Sets whether hardware acceleration is required.
/ The default value is `Some(true)`
/ ## Platform-specific
/ This option will be taken into account on the following platforms:
/   * MacOS
/   * Linux using EGL with either X or Wayland
/   * Windows using EGL or WGL
/   * Android using EGL
inline

defs.name: Latest
defs.docs: Request the latest version of the "best" API of this platform.

/ On desktop, will try OpenGL.

defs.docs: Request a specific version of a specific API.

/ Example: `GlRequest::Specific(Api::OpenGl, (3, 3))`.

defs.name: GlThenGles
defs.docs:
If OpenGL is available, create an OpenGL context with the specified
 `opengl_version`. Else if OpenGL ES or WebGL is available, create a
 context with the specified `opengles_version`.

attributes.value: / If OpenGL is available, create an OpenGL context with the specified
/ `opengl_version`. Else if OpenGL ES or WebGL is available, create a
/ context with the specified `opengles_version`.

defs.docs:
Describes the OpenGL API and version that are being requested when a context
 is created.

attributes.value: / Describes the OpenGL API and version that are being requested when a context
/ is created.

defs.docs: Extract the desktop GL version, if any.

attributes.value: / Extract the desktop GL version, if any.

defs.name: GL_CORE
defs.docs:
The minimum core profile GL context. Useful for getting the minimum
 required GL version while still running on OSX, which often forbids
 the compatibility profile features.

attributes.value: / The minimum core profile GL context. Useful for getting the minimum
/ required GL version while still running on OSX, which often forbids
/ the compatibility profile features.

defs.name: NotRobust
defs.docs:
Not everything is checked. Your application can crash if you do
 something wrong with your shaders.

attributes.value: / Not everything is checked. Your application can crash if you do
/ something wrong with your shaders.

defs.name: NoError
defs.docs:
The driver doesn't check anything. This option is very dangerous.
 Please know what you're doing before using it. See the
 `GL_KHR_no_error` extension.

attributes.value: / The driver doesn't check anything. This option is very dangerous.
/ Please know what you're doing before using it. See the
/ `GL_KHR_no_error` extension.
/ Since this option is purely an optimization, no error will be returned
/ if the backend doesn't support it. Instead it will automatically
/ fall back to `NotRobust`.

defs.name: RobustNoResetNotification
defs.docs:
Everything is checked to avoid any crash. The driver will attempt to
 avoid any problem, but if a problem occurs the behavior is
 implementation-defined. You are just guaranteed not to get a crash.

attributes.value: / Everything is checked to avoid any crash. The driver will attempt to
/ avoid any problem, but if a problem occurs the behavior is
/ implementation-defined. You are just guaranteed not to get a crash.

defs.name: TryRobustNoResetNotification
defs.docs:
Same as `RobustNoResetNotification` but the context creation doesn't
 fail if it's not supported.

attributes.value: / Same as `RobustNoResetNotification` but the context creation doesn't
/ fail if it's not supported.

defs.name: RobustLoseContextOnReset
defs.docs:
Everything is checked to avoid any crash. If a problem occurs, the
 context will enter a "context lost" state. It must then be
 recreated. For the moment, glutin doesn't provide a way to recreate
 a context with the same window :-/

attributes.value: / Everything is checked to avoid any crash. If a problem occurs, the
/ context will enter a "context lost" state. It must then be
/ recreated. For the moment, glutin doesn't provide a way to recreate
/ a context with the same window :-/

defs.name: TryRobustLoseContextOnReset
defs.docs:
Same as `RobustLoseContextOnReset` but the context creation doesn't
 fail if it's not supported.

attributes.value: / Same as `RobustLoseContextOnReset` but the context creation doesn't
/ fail if it's not supported.

defs.name: Robustness
defs.docs:
Specifies the tolerance of the OpenGL context to faults. If you accept raw
 OpenGL commands and/or raw shader code from an untrusted source, you should
 definitely care about this.

attributes.value: / Specifies the tolerance of the OpenGL context to faults. If you accept raw
/ OpenGL commands and/or raw shader code from an untrusted source, you should
/ definitely care about this.

defs.name: None
defs.docs: Doesn't do anything. Most notably doesn't flush.

attributes.value: / Doesn't do anything. Most notably doesn't flush.

defs.name: Flush
defs.docs:
Flushes the context that was previously current as if `glFlush` was
 called.

attributes.value: / Flushes the context that was previously current as if `glFlush` was
/ called.

defs.name: ReleaseBehavior
defs.docs: The behavior of the driver when you change the current context.

attributes.value: / The behavior of the driver when you change the current context.

defs.name: PixelFormat
defs.value: PixelFormat { hardware_accelerated, color_bits, alpha_bits, depth_bits, stencil_bits, stereoscopy, double_buffer, multisampling, srgb }
defs.docs: Describes a possible format. Unused.

attributes.value: / Describes a possible format. Unused.
allow(missing_docs)

defs.name: PixelFormatRequirements
defs.value: PixelFormatRequirements { hardware_accelerated, color_bits, float_color_buffer, alpha_bits, depth_bits, stencil_bits, double_buffer, multisampling, stereoscopy, srgb, release_behavior }
defs.docs: Describes how the backend should choose a pixel format.

attributes.value: / Describes how the backend should choose a pixel format.

defs.name: hardware_accelerated
defs.docs:
If true, only hardware-accelerated formats will be considered. If
 false, only software renderers. `None` means "don't care". Default
 is `Some(true)`.

attributes.value: / If true, only hardware-accelerated formats will be considered. If
/ false, only software renderers. `None` means "don't care". Default
/ is `Some(true)`.

defs.name: color_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the color buffer, excluding alpha. `None`
 means "don't care". The default is `Some(24)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the color buffer, excluding alpha. `None`
/ means "don't care". The default is `Some(24)`.

defs.name: float_color_buffer
defs.docs:
If true, the color buffer must be in a floating point format. Default
 is `false`.

attributes.value: / If true, the color buffer must be in a floating point format. Default
/ is `false`.
/ Using floating points allows you to write values outside of the `[0.0,
/ 1.0]` range.

defs.name: alpha_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the alpha in the color buffer. `None` means
 "don't care". The default is `Some(8)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the alpha in the color buffer. `None` means
/ "don't care". The default is `Some(8)`.

defs.name: depth_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
 The default value is `Some(24)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
/ The default value is `Some(24)`.

defs.name: stencil_bits
defs.docs:
Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
 The default value is `Some(8)`.

attributes.value: / Minimum number of bits for the depth buffer. `None` means "don't care".
/ The default value is `Some(8)`.

defs.name: double_buffer
defs.docs:
If true, only double-buffered formats will be considered. If false,
 only single-buffer formats. `None` means "don't care". The default
 is `Some(true)`.

attributes.value: / If true, only double-buffered formats will be considered. If false,
/ only single-buffer formats. `None` means "don't care". The default
/ is `Some(true)`.

defs.name: multisampling
defs.docs:
Contains the minimum number of samples per pixel in the color, depth
 and stencil buffers. `None` means "don't care". Default is `None`.
 A value of `Some(0)` indicates that multisampling must not be enabled.

attributes.value: / Contains the minimum number of samples per pixel in the color, depth
/ and stencil buffers. `None` means "don't care". Default is `None`.
/ A value of `Some(0)` indicates that multisampling must not be enabled.

defs.name: stereoscopy
defs.docs:
If true, only stereoscopic formats will be considered. If false, only
 non-stereoscopic formats. The default is `false`.

attributes.value: / If true, only stereoscopic formats will be considered. If false, only
/ non-stereoscopic formats. The default is `false`.

defs.name: srgb
defs.docs:
If true, only sRGB-capable formats will be considered. If false, don't
 care. The default is `false`.

attributes.value: / If true, only sRGB-capable formats will be considered. If false, don't
/ care. The default is `false`.

defs.name: release_behavior
defs.docs: The behavior when changing the current context. Default is `Flush`.

attributes.value: / The behavior when changing the current context. Default is `Flush`.

defs.name: GlAttributes
defs.value: GlAttributes { sharing, version, profile, debug, robustness, vsync }
defs.docs: Attributes to use when creating an OpenGL context.

attributes.value: / Attributes to use when creating an OpenGL context.

defs.name: sharing
defs.docs: An existing context with which some OpenGL objects get shared.

attributes.value: / An existing context with which some OpenGL objects get shared.
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: version
defs.docs: Version to try create. See `GlRequest` for more infos.

attributes.value: / Version to try create. See `GlRequest` for more infos.
/ The default is `Latest`.

defs.name: profile
defs.docs: OpenGL profile to use.

attributes.value: / OpenGL profile to use.
/ The default is `None`.

defs.name: debug
defs.docs: Whether to enable the `debug` flag of the context.

attributes.value: / Whether to enable the `debug` flag of the context.
/ Debug contexts are usually slower but give better error reporting.
/ The default is `true` in debug mode and `false` in release mode.

defs.name: robustness
defs.docs: How the OpenGL context should detect errors.

attributes.value: / How the OpenGL context should detect errors.
/ The default is `NotRobust` because this is what is typically expected
/ when you create an OpenGL context. However for safety you should
/ consider `TryRobustLoseContextOnReset`.

defs.name: vsync
defs.docs:
Whether to use vsync. If vsync is enabled, calling `swap_buffers` will
 block until the screen refreshes. This is typically used to prevent
 screen tearing.

attributes.value: / Whether to use vsync. If vsync is enabled, calling `swap_buffers` will
/ block until the screen refreshes. This is typically used to prevent
/ screen tearing.
/ The default is `false`.

defs.name: map_sharing
defs.value: pub fn map_sharing<F, T>(Self, F) -> GlAttributes<T> where F: FnOnce(S) -> T
defs.docs: Turns the `sharing` parameter into another type by calling a closure.

attributes.value: / Turns the `sharing` parameter into another type by calling a closure.
inline
